instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message: This board had some light spill damage on the right side of the board (looking at it from the bottom) so it wasn't anywhere near the power button on the left, but I'm getting nothing out of the power button. It has the click so mechanically it seems fine, but it does nothing at any time. No visible damage or corrosion. The Touch ID is also giving a "Fingerprint Limit Reached" error even after running xartutil ?erase-all in Terminal but I'm not sure if that's related. Any idea where to start with this?

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message:
Disconnect Touch ID and check if R5225/26 pads act as power button.
If yes, you have bad Touch ID.

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message: That's not turning it off. Tried many times with different tweezers just to make sure I was making good contact. Does nothing.

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message:
Did you check for 3V presence on these pads?
If yes, check if PM_PWRBTN_L reacts when trigger SMC_ONOFF_L.

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message: Yes, 3.3V was on SMC_ONOFF_L. 3.3V is also on PM_PWRBTN_L. PM_PWRBTN_L is going low though when I trigger the R5225/26 pads.

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message: To force it off, you must keep SMC_ONFF_L low for 4-5 seconds.

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message: Ok, got it, yes, thanks, that does turn it off. So you think the Touch ID/power button needs to be replaced then?

threads.title: 820-00239 Power button not working.
threads.message:
Yeah, I pulled it and found a tiny tear under the microscope. I couldn't see it normally. This came into us with a bunch of screws and connectors missing. Not surprising that it was damaged.

Thanks for the help getting this figured out.
